awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Program in Nanotechnology for Biology and Bioengineering
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Johns Hopkins University, located in Baltimore, Maryland, will support training of 14 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021. This award is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program and the Division of Biological Infrastructure (DBI) in the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Division of Engineering Education and Centers (EEC) in the Directorate for Engineering. The REU program will provide undergraduate students with a challenging research experience in the rapidly growing area of nanobiotechnology, a discipline at the interface of biology, chemistry, physics, materials science, and engineering. REU research focuses on engineering for cancer therapies, stem cells and regenerative engineering, and diagnostic tools engineered for early detection. In addition to research, the REU program includes oral and poster presentations, scientific seminars, journal club, communication seminars, field trips to industry/government partners, and multiple social activities. Students are required to complete Responsible Conduct of Research training and lab safety training before starting research. Underrepresented minorities, students from institutions with limited research opportunities, first generation students, students from families with a low to moderate income, and students with disabilities are encouraged to apply. Students apply online and are selected by an admissions committee of faculty reviewers.  

It is anticipated that a total of 42 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. The overall objective of this program is to provide REU students with a truly unique educational experience, with the research experience at the core, while at the same time serving as an ideal foundation for future graduate research.

A common web-based assessment tool, SALG URSSA, used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting https://inbt.jhu.edu/education/undergraduate/nanobio-reu/, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Denis Wirtz at wirtz@jhu.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Efrosini Kokkoli at kokkoli@jhu.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The Johns Hopkins University REU program in Nanotechnology for Biology and Bioengineering, housed within the Institute for NanoBioTechnology, provided summer research training for 14 students in the summer of 2023. The cohort included eleven women and nine minorities. The program attracted an application pool of 520 highly diverse undergraduate students. 

This REU has met its overall goal of having its students participate in a unique research, educational, and professional experience with research being the focus. This REU program laid the foundation for interest in graduate research, future student presentations, and published papers. After the REU experience, the eleven interns surveyed reported that they are likely or very likely to pursue a PhD program in STEM in the future. Additionally, all of them reported that they are likely or very likely to pursue a career that includes research.

The REU students performed research in labs across different divisions of Johns Hopkins University within participating departments: biomedical engineering, radiology, mechanical engineering, chemical and biomolecular engineering, and materials science and engineering.  The program has worked with 12 faculty mentors and labs to ensure a diverse range of opportunities for research interest in biomaterials, bioengineering, biophysics, nanofabrication, cell engineering, and tissue engineering

REU students participated in seminars and various workshops focusing on topics such as responsible conduct of research, oral presentations, publishing, graduate school admissions, creating a scientific poster, and a journal club. The development workshops are in addition to a scientific seminar series, where the students learned about career paths and cutting-edge research from distinguished faculty. The students gave oral and poster presentations of their research. Students fully participated in lab research and projects that have an intellectual merit.  Examples of projects during the summer of 2023 include:

  • Extracellular Vesicle-Loaded Microgels as a Preventative Method for Radiation Fibrosis.
  • Investigating the immuno-stromal crosstalk in aged microenvironments of Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL).
  • Quantifying Protein Affinity: Assessing Immunofibers as an Alternative for Protein Purification.

 

This program was able to introduce undergraduates to exciting developments with emphasis on engineering for cancer therapies, diagnostic tools engineered for early detection, and stem cell and regenerative engineering. REU students were vital in the planning and progress in all projects they were assigned.  These projects promoted learning, skill development, career exploration, and teaching.  At the end of the summer, the students presented posters on their work at the School of Medicine’s CARES Symposium.

Overall, the program in Nanotechnology for Biology and Bioengineering, has attracted, trained, and mentored a diverse group of students.  

 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/02/2024
Modified by: Denis Wirtz
